moves.1. e4 d6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bc4 Be7: Despite appearances, the doubled paws are fully compensated for by the weakness of the backward c pawn on the open file.
moves.18... Be7 19. Qe3 Bb5 20. Nc5 Rxa1 21. R: Looking for tactical possibilities if the N retreats.
moves.22. Rc1 f6 23. Nh4 Ra8: This appears to be going after pawns but the real threat is a back rank mate.
moves.24... Bxc5 25. Rxc5: ? Loses the exchange rather than a piece.
moves.25... Qxc5: Of course, if the Queen is taken, ...Ra8 is mate.
It seems Black has a simple win, but White has not given up yet.
moves.29... Rd1 30. Qg3 Rd7 31. Qg4 c5 32. Ne3: ...Bc6??. When so far ahead, do not get careless!
moves.34. Qe6+ Kf8 35. Qxc6: Black is still ahad but has numerous threats. Black decides that the Queen and pawn ending is winnable and since the centralized N is a threat....
moves.35... Rxd5: This leads to a winnable Queen and pawn ending (if Black is careful).
moves.43. Qb5 Qb1+ 44. Kh2 Qxb3 45. Qe8+ Kh6: This is White's only good plan, an attempt to trap the king.
moves.46... Qc2+ 47. Kg3 Qd3+ 48. Kh4: If the K retreats, Black wins. So White threatens mate.
moves.48... g5#: But so did Black! Morale, do not let big advantages lull you into carelessness!
